channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 10
item.description: Ex-C.I.A. technician says he is the source behind U.S. government leaks; North and South Korea agree to talks; flooding continues in Central and Eastern Europe; an organization aiding persecuted academics; Tony winners are announced; and Nadal wins a record eighth French Open.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: Car Bombs at Market in Central Iraq Kill 15
item.description: Attackers detonated explosives hidden in a produce-laden pickup truck and two other vehicles parked around a market in central Iraq early Monday, killing 15 people in the latest in a spike of violence ravaging the country.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: India Ink: B.J.P. Patriarch Relinquishes Party Posts After Modi’s Promotion
item.description: L.K. Advani’s decision follows Narendra Modi’s appointment as the lead B.J.P. campaigner for the 2014 national elections.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Gujarat chief minister Narendra Modi, right, and L.K. Advani, left, greeting supporters in Ahmedabad, Gujarat on Dec. 25, 2007.

item.title: Indonesia Asks Saudi Arabia to Extend Deadline for Workers
item.description: The request followed unrest at Indonesia’s consulate in Jeddah, where thousands of workers waited in the sun to get new papers and a woman died of suspected heat exhaustion.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Danube Crests Near Record Level in Budapest
item.description: A proposal to extend a state of emergency was submitted to Parliament on Monday as the Danube peaked at about 29 feet on Sunday night.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Afghan Forces Quell Attack on Kabul Airport
item.description: Gunmen and suicide bombers were said to have fired upon the part of the airport maintained by international forces, but the security forces acted quickly to put down the attack.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and SHARIFULLAH SAHAK

item.title: The Lede: N.S.A. Whistle-Blower Revealed in Video
item.description: Edward Snowden, who worked until several weeks ago as a private contractor at a National Security Agency facility in Hawaii, explained in a video interview why he had leaked classified information about the scope of America’s surveillance efforts.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Kabul Airport Attacked, Afghans Say
item.description: Gunmen and suicide bombers attacked Kabul International Airport before dawn on Monday, Afghan officials said.
item.dc:creator: By SHARIFULLAH SAHAK and ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Amid China's Boom, Fake Wines Proliferate
item.description: Given the high margins and the demand, the counterfeiters tend to focus on European fine wines, reusing official bottles and creating labels that look European.
item.dc:creator: By TERRIL YUE JONES | REUTERS

item.title: Indonesians Irked by Delay With Saudis
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of foreign workers in Saudi Arabia are trying to rectify their immigration status by July 3, when the government will resume a crackdown on illegal labor.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Edward Snowden, Ex-C.I.A. Worker, Says He Disclosed U.S. Surveillance
item.description: A British newspaper identified its source as Edward Snowden, a former C.I.A. employee who has worked at the National Security Agency as a contractor.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Insurgents Attack Military Side of Afghan Airport
item.description: Insurgents on Monday attacked the military side of Kabul's international airport, which houses a NATO headquarters, and explosions and gunfire were occurring, Afghan army and police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Rare Visit to Kurds by Iraqi Leader
item.description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq visited the Kurdistan region for the first time in more than two years in an effort to resolve an oil and land dispute.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Iran Candidates Toe Hard Line for Nuclear Bid
item.description: Iran’s presidential campaign is an example of how the Obama administration’s tough sanctions seem to have only stiffened the country’s will to resist compromise on its nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cheers went up Saturday for Hassan Rowhani, the candidate closest to the reform camp. Still, he backs Iran’s nuclear program.

item.title: Protester Dies in Clash That Apparently Involved Hezbollah Supporters
item.description: A protester was shot and killed near the Iranian Embassy in Beirut, apparently in a clash between supporters and opponents of Hezbollah, the powerful Lebanese Shiite Muslim organization.
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and HALA DROUBI

item.title: Sudan Says Pipeline Shutdown Is ‘Reversible’
item.description: The announcement by Sudan’s information minister on Sunday suggests that the country was seeking to ward off another escalation in tensions with South Sudan.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Pushing Back, and Raising a Glass, in Turkey
item.description: Drinking has become intertwined with broader complaints in Turkey, where Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan has said that “religion demands” curbs on alcohol.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ed Ou for The New York Times
item.media:description: Drinking beer in Taksim Square. Drinking has become intertwined with the broader complaints of Turks fighting what they see as rising authoritarianism.

item.title: Moisés Ville Journal: Traditions Fade in Argentine Haven for Jews
item.description: In the 1940s, Moisés Ville had 5,000 people, 4 synagogues and a theater for Yiddish-language troupes. But now, the Argentine town appears ready to fade into history.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Libyan Violence Threatens to Undercut Power of Militias
item.description: After deadly weekend clashes, signs emerged that Libyans’ shock at the violence against civilians might weaken the influence of the groups’ leaders.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Activists Ask Obama to Shed Light on Shell Companies
item.description: Anticorruption activists want the president to back public registration of shell-company owners, which they hope can deter tax evasion and money laundering.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: News Analysis: Obama and Xi Try to Avoid a Cold War Mentality
item.description: President Obama and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, emerged from talks determined to avoid the pitfalls of a rising power confronting an established one.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and President Obama at the Sunnylands in Southern California on Saturday.

item.title: North and South Korea to Discuss Restoring Economic and Other Ties
item.description: The agreement was a clear sign that North and South Korea were easing tensions and moving toward a thaw after years of recriminations that hit a peak earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: City’s Newest Immigrant Enclaves, From Little Guyana to Meokjagolmok
item.description: Sri Lankans have gathered on Staten Island, Arabs in Brooklyn, Ghanaians in the Bronx: A guide to the new immigrant enclaves.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left, an Arab neighborhood in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn; a Sri Lankan New Year’s celebration on Staten Island; a Mexican area of Sunset Park, Brooklyn; Ghanaians in the Bronx, where their large immigrant group is centered.

item.title: Hungary Braced as Danube Floods Parts of Budapest
item.description: A wet spring has swollen rivers across Hungary, Germany, Austria and the Czech Republic, forcing evacuations, disrupting traffic and causing major damage.
item.dc:creator: By PALKO KARASZ and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Volunteers rested next to the river Elbe on Sunday in Magdeburg, Germany.

item.title: Letter From Washington: Research Forgotten by Budget Cuts
item.description: The long-term consequences of U.S. budget cuts, in more than a few cases, are ominous. There is no better case study than Alzheimer's disease.
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW
